title: How to Properly Slaughter a Cow Under the Kosher Method Shechitah

steps.title: Inspect the blade of your knife.
steps.content: Inspect the blade of your knife. The length of the blade should be twice the width of the animal’s neck. [3] X Research source Make sure that there are absolutely no nicks or unevenness. Any blemish on the blade at all, even one big enough for a human hair to fall into, renders the knife unacceptable for kosher slaughter. The knife must be sharpened to such a sharp point that if the Shochet were to slice off their finger, they would feel no pain. [4] X Trustworthy Source Chabad.org Online resource for information related to Chabad-Lubavitch and Jewish culture Go to source

steps.title: If the animal is ill or injured, it is no longer considered Kosher.
steps.content: If the animal is ill or injured, it is no longer considered Kosher. This has two purposes. First, it ensures the quality of the meat because an ill or injured animal should not be eaten anyway. Second, it provides a disincentive for Kosher farms to partake in the methods of other farms, because if the cow is hurt in any way, it cannot be slaughtered. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Restrain the animal, then cut the esophagus.
steps.content: Restrain the animal, then cut the esophagus. If the animal is injured during the restraining, it is no longer considered kosher. [6] X Trustworthy Source Official UK government website Official website for the public sector of the UK government Go to source Cut the esophagus, trachea, carotid arteries, and jugular veins in one quick incision. The incision must not at all pull or tear, and must be performed in one motion free of any pause. If done correctly, the animal will die within 2 seconds. [7] X Research source Drain the blood of the animal completely. Eating blood is not Kosher, because the blood contains the soul of the animal. [8] X Research source [9] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure there are no defects.
steps.content: Make sure there are no defects. This is especially important for mammals (cows, sheep, goats, etc.). The lungs must be inflated to check for unwanted holes and for signs of lung disease. If there are holes or signs of active lung disease, the cow is not considered kosher. [10] X Trustworthy Source Chabad.org Online resource for information related to Chabad-Lubavitch and Jewish culture Go to source

steps.title: These include blood vessels and the sciatic nerve.
steps.content: These include blood vessels and the sciatic nerve. If you are Ashkenazi and have no tradition of removing the sciatic nerve, you do not have to do so. As with the lungs, removing these parts only applies to mammals. Remove all fat surrounding the vital organs, as well. Internal fat, known in Hebrew as “cheilev” is not considered Kosher. [11] X Research source
